article.headline: New Mexico 71, Utah 50
article.story:
DENVER (AP) -- An errant elbow late in the first half left New
Mexico point guard Mandi Moore on her hands and knees, blood
dripping from her mouth. She woozily walked back to the bench and
wasn't going to go back in anytime soon.

Cause for concern? Not for New Mexico. Not with freshman Katie
Montgomery on the bench.

Montgomery scored 10 of her 14 points in the second half in
place of Moore, helping New Mexico successfully defend its Mountain
West Conference tournament title with a 71-50 win over Utah on
Saturday.

"Mandi is our leader on the floor, but as far as
basketball-wise, we weren't worrying about Katie taking over,"
said Melissa Forest, who led Utah with four 3-pointers and 18
points. "She came in, stepped up and led our team from the point
guard. She took over the team and hit some big baskets."

Moore went out with just over minute left in the first half
after Utah's Lana Sitterud caught her with an elbow while fighting
for a rebound. She had several stitches at halftime and played
sparingly in the second half.

Montgomery, who averaged 4.8 points in the regular season,
started the second half in Moore's place and the Lobos didn't miss
a beat.

New Mexico hit seven of its first eight shots to open with a
16-2 run, turning a halftime tie into a 14-point lead.

Montgomery hit a 3-pointer that bounced on the front rim and in
late in the run, and Judy Vogt capped it with a pullup jumper that
made it 48-34 with 13 minutes left.

"Mandi is our team leader. I knew that when she went out in the
first half that it was scary and that I had to step up,"
Montgomery said. "The team had to get points out of me. We all
came together and everybody shot well."

No doubt.

New Mexico (23-7), the tournament's top seed after tying Utah in
the regular season, shot 55 percent and was 10-of-16 on 3-pointers
to reach the NCAA tournament for the third straight year.

An NCAA quarterfinalist last year, the Lobos will host the first
two rounds March 20 and 22, entering the tournament with 11
straight wins.

"They shot the lights out and every kid contributed," Utah
coach Elaine Elliott said.

Shona Thorburn had 13 points and Kim Smith added 12 for No. 2
seed Utah (24-7), which shot just 31 percent in its first
conference final since winning the tournament in 2000.

Despite their worst loss of the season, the Utes should be a
good bet to reach the NCAA tournament for the eighth time in 10
years when the brackets are announced Sunday.

"If you have an RPI (rating) of 30, you've won 24 games and you
can't get into the tournament, I don't know what that says about
the future for many teams," Elliott said. "What more do you want
to do?"

Utah, the Mountain West's best shooting team in the regular
season, got off to a slow start for the second straight game.

The Utes didn't have a field goal in the first 5{ minutes of
their 59-55 win over UNLV in the semifinals Friday and weren't much
better in this one.

Utah missed nine of its first 10 shots, including a wide-open
layup by Kelsey Stireman, and had just two points the first four
minutes.

But just like the semifinals, the Utes came back. Utah used an
11-4 run to get within one, then took its first lead at 20-19 on
Carley Marshall's cut to the basket with 8:08 left.

This time, it didn't last.

The Utes missed five of their first six shots in the second half
and had just four points with four turnovers in the first eight
minutes.

"I was tired, but I expect it," Thorburn said. "I'm assuming
they were just as fatigued as we were."

Utah did find a way to get Smith going early, but she couldn't
sustain it.

The two-time Mountain West player of the year had just 10 points
on 4-of-10 shooting against UNLV in the semifinals, but didn't face
the same kind of ball-denying defense early against New Mexico.
Smith was 4-for-6 for eight points in the first half.

But the opportunities dried up in the second half after New
Mexico switched to a zone defense.

Smith had just four points after halftime on 1-of-5 shooting.

"I decided that the zone might be a little more effective and
we went into the zone," New Mexico coach Don Flanagan said. "It
was giving them some problems. They were trying to get it inside,
but our interior defense was doing a great job."
